qas.question: When were the mosaics at the Great Palace of Constantinople commissioned?
What is considered the most important surviving mosaic of the Justinian age?

answers.text: The portrait of a moustached man

qas.question: What was the small vaulted room in the Great Palace of Constantinople called?
Vine Scroll motifs are classified under what kind of tradition?
When were the mosaics at the church in Thessaloniki created?

context: Important fragments survived from the mosaic floor of the Great Palace of Constantinople which was commissioned <a0_0>during Justinian's reign<a0_0/>. The figures, animals, plants all are entirely classical but they are scattered before a plain background. <a1_0>The portrait of a moustached man<a1_0/>, probably a Gothic chieftain, is considered the most important surviving mosaic of the Justinianian age. The so-called <a2_0>small sekreton<a2_0/> of the palace was built during Justin II's reign around 565–577. Some fragments survive from the mosaics of this vaulted room. The vine scroll motifs are very similar to those in the Santa Constanza and they still closely follow the <a3_0>Classical<a3_0/> tradition. There are remains of floral decoration in the Church of the Acheiropoietos in Thessaloniki (<a4_0>5th–6th centuries<a4_0/>).
